awd_titl_txt: ICES:Small: The Effects of Shocks on Interacting Social and Physical Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how exogenous shocks that take place in one network affect the structure and evolution of other networks. The objective of the project is to gain a better understanding of the interaction between social and physical networks at critical junctures, allowing both assessment of the conditions of failure and rehabilitation of systems that fail because they are connected to other systems that fail. The main focus is on three types of interrelations between pairs of networks: 1) Overlapping networks: two or more networks that share nodes and/or edges. 2) Complementary networks: two or more networks that perform partially or fully complementary functions (such as e-commerce and shipping networks). 3) Competitive networks: networks in which the flow of goods, information, or energy in one is inversely correlated to the flow of similar items in the other (such as airline and rail transportation).

The intellectual merit of the project rests in explaining the effect of shocks on the structure of interacting social and physical networks. It will allow new insights into the cross-network effects of shocks as a function of both the structure of individual networks and the type of relationships between pairs of networks.

The broader impacts of the project include the development of methods and computerized infrastructure for predicting the impact of a future shock in one network on other networks, potentially providing decision makers with insights into structuring network ties in a way that will optimize the effects of a shock in one network. Finally, this project offers graduate student training and experiencing in theory development, designing mathematical and agent-based models, and empirical evaluation of theoretical models.

por.por_cntn:
Our project was set to examine how shocks (man made or natuarl) disasters affect the way in which social (political, communications) and physical (transportation) networks re-organize following such shocks. We also aimed to find ways to determine linkages between social and physical networks.

In order to address these issues, we developed methods to determine spillover across networks--that is, whether a relationship between two units that exists in one network (for example whether two people are neighbors), develops into a relationship between the same units in another networks (the same neighbors become friends). Our methods allow us to distinguish between actual spillover (a relationship in one network "causes" a relationship in another network), and spillover that may be due to chance. We demonstrated this method by analyzing the effect of international alliances between states and international trade between the same states, as well as a relationship in a community of software developers, between a communication network and collaboration in software development.

We also modeled how shocks can spread in a network not via direct contact (or communication) by by "hopping" over some units that transmit information about the shock, but they, themselves, are not affected by such shocks. We used this model to explain how the spread of unrest in the Middle East spread into some states, but not to other. The latter, it turns out, served as a bridge for communication about unrest, but they themselves were "immune" to political unrest.

We developed computer simulations that examined how shocks affect international networks. These simulations focused on shocks such as wars that change the identity of friends and foes in international relations, as well as on economic crises or changes in capabilities that affect the abiility of states to trade or form alliances. We tested the results of these computer simulations on data involving international alliances and internaitonal trade over the period of 1816 to 2010.

We also analyzed how violent events (e.g., terrorist attacks) reflect media networks. We found that major terrorist attacks generate temporary spikes in the degree to which two countries are mentioned together in the same media report, and the more serious the event, the higher the media spike.

Finaly, we are in the process of examining the relationship between a physical network and communication networks in the case of the 2010 Icelandic volcano erupotion which caused a major disrubption of air travel in, from, and to Europe. We were just able to acquire the air travel data, and we are in the process of analyzing it.

In the process we put together a major data repository that contains network information of multiple networks (some of which co-evolve over a very long time span), software packages, and simulation software, and a general website containing data, publications, and additional information. All this is available to the general public and scholarsly communities at http://spins.faculty.ucdavis.edu.

Taken together, these studies provide important insights into (a) the extent, manner and magnitude of interdependence between different networks, (b) the way in which shocks propagate across networks, and (c) the manner in which different networks re-organize following shocks. These methods, data, and empirical researh span a wide array of discipines, issues, and applications. As such they should have broad appeal across a large number of scientific disciplines.
